SEARCH
Package org.example

Class MyArrayList<E>

java.lang.Object
org.example.MyArrayList<E>
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable
public class MyArrayList<E> extends Object implements Serializable
MyArrayList is my attempt to recreate ArrayList from scratch.

Possibilities:

- Can hold any types via use of generics;

- Can be created with default capacity and with passing array;

- Can find it's length;

- Can add a new element with corresponding type to the end of the array or any other place of array;

- Can replace an element of array with passed element with index;

- Can delete any element with index;

- Can get any element with index;

- Can clear the array from elements;

- Can print all content of the array;

- Can sort the array with QuickSort algorithm that uses Comparator Comparator;

- Can be Serializable Serializable.

---------------------------------------------------

Author:
Denis Reznikov

  • Constructor Details

    • MyArrayList

      public MyArrayList()
      The default constructor which will create the empty arrMyArrayList.

    • MyArrayList

      public MyArrayList(Collection<? extends E> arr)

      The constructor which creates the MyArrayList from a collection like Arrays.asList(...)

      Parameters:
      arr - is a collection which elements you want to use via the MyArrayList.

  • Method Details

    • length

      public int length()
      Calculates the length of the arrMyArrayList, i.e., of the MyArrayList via for loop
      Returns:
      length of the arrMyArrayList

    • add

      public void add(E element)
      Adds an element to the end of the arrMyArrayList. It calculates a length of the arrMyArrayList than calculates new length and assigns a new array with elements from a previous arr plus a new element to the arrMyArrayList.
      Parameters:
      element - the element which you want to add to the arrMyArrayList

    • add

      public void add(int i, E element)
      Replaces an element in the arrMyArrayList at the index i with the element. It calculates a previous length of the arrMyArrayList then calculates a new length, and then it checks if it can replace a previous element with the new element.
      Parameters:
      i - index of the previous element which you want to replace with the new element.
      element - the element which you want to have in place of a previous element at the index i

    • addWithOffset

      public void addWithOffset(int i, E element)
      Adds the element to the given index i with an offset of other part of arrMyArrayList if necessary. It calculates a length of the arrMyArrayList then checks the given index i if you can or can't add the element here. If everything's okay then it creates three arrays: an array before the index i inclusively, an array after the index i, and an array which contains only the new element. Then it connects them together and replaces arrMyArrayList with the new array.
      Parameters:
      i - index at which you want to place the element.
      element - an element you want to place at the index i.

    • delete

      public void delete(int i)
      Deletes an element at the index i. It calculates a length of the arrMyArrayList then it creates two arrays: an array with elements before i element and an array with elements after i element. After that it connects that arrays and reassign arrMyArrayList with it.
      Parameters:
      i - an index of an element which you want to delete.

    • get

      public E get(int i)
      Gets an element at the index i out of the arrMyArrayList.
      Parameters:
      i - an index of the element which you want to get
      Returns:
      an element which you want to get

    • clear

      public void clear()
      Clears the arrMyArrayList from any elements by reassigning it to the DEFAULT_EMPTY_ARR.

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Changes behavior so now it creates a string of all elements of the arrMyArrayList via Arrays.toString() method.
      Overrides:
      toString in class Object
      Returns:
      string which contains all elements of the arrMyArrayList

    • quickMergeSort

      public void quickMergeSort()
      QuickMergeSort realisation from scratch. It creates the MyArrayList with all elements and passes it with the array arrResult which at the end will be a sorted version of the used array. The method quickMergeSortRecursion uses the index as a first index of the element pivot with which all other elements will compare.

      It deletes the element from the arrMyArrayList and starts checking all elements of the arrMyArrayList if they're less than or equals the pivot. If that's true than all elements will be added to the arrLeft which will be used inside the quickMergeSortRecursion method.

      That method will do practically the same process as the quickMergeSort but with a moment - at the end when it have an array with two elements it will compare them and add them to the array arrResul with ASC order. If an array have only one element than it will add it. If zero elements than it will stop.

      At the end quickMergeSortRecursionwill add all elements of the array arrLeft in ASC order to the array arrResult and than it adds the pivot itself to that array because all other element will be bigger than it so we can safely add it .

      Then the process repeats but with the array arrRight which will have all the elements bigger than the pivot and it'll go to the quickMergeSortRecursion method which will add to the array arrResult all elements bigger than the pivot.

      At the end the array arrMyArrayList will be cleared from all it's elements and all the elements of the sorted array arrResult will be added to the empty arrMyArrayList via for-loop.

    • quickMergeSort

      public void quickMergeSort(Comparator<E> comparator)
      QuickMergeSort realization for objects with the comparator. It creates the MyArrayList with all elements and passes it with the array arrResult which at the end will be a sorted version of the used array. The method quickMergeSortRecursion uses the index as a first index of the element pivot with which all other elements will compare.

      It deletes the element from the arrMyArrayList and starts checking all elements of the arrMyArrayList if they're less than or equals the pivot. If that's true than all elements will be added to the arrLeft which will be used inside the quickMergeSortRecursion method.

      That method will do practically the same process as the quickMergeSort but with a moment - at the end when it have an array with two elements it will compare them and add them to the array arrResul with ASC order. If an array have only one element than it will add it. If zero elements than it will stop.

      At the end quickMergeSortRecursionwill add all elements of the array arrLeft in ASC order to the array arrResult and than it adds the pivot itself to that array because all other element will be bigger than it so we can safely add it .

      Then the process repeats but with the array arrRight which will have all the elements bigger than the pivot and it'll go to the quickMergeSortRecursion method which will add to the array arrResult all elements bigger than the pivot.

      At the end the array arrMyArrayList will be cleared from all it's elements and all the elements of the sorted array arrResult will be added to the empty arrMyArrayList via for-loop.
      Parameters:
      comparator - used to compare object with it's compare method.

    • quickSort

      public void quickSort()
      My QuickSort realization. Method is used as a start for the quickSort algorithm for user's convenience. Algorithm itself uses array as arrMyArrayList, indexes of the beginning and of the end of the array. Firstly it sorts the left part of the array by choosing the pivot with the indexEnd. Next it will compare each element of the arr between the indexBegin and the indexEnd and if an element will be smaller than the pivot than it will go to the left of the pivot. When the left side will be gone it will start to sort right side.
